tasks: Gather necessary components (LED, resistor, battery, wires)
Learn about LED polarity and how to identify anode/cathode
Calculate appropriate resistor value for your LED and power source
Build a simple circuit on a breadboard to light the LED
Test the circuit and troubleshoot if needed
Document your process with photos
Learn about different wire gauges and their uses
Practice stripping different types of wires without damaging the conductor
Learn to strip multiple wires quickly and consistently
Practice stripping wire ends for different connector types
Learn proper wire preparation for soldering
resources: Tool Selection Guide: 'Choosing the Right Wire Strippers'

tasks: Choose an appropriate beginner electronics kit
Identify all components in the kit
Follow assembly instructions step by step
Test the completed circuit
Document any challenges and how you overcame them
Create a working log of your build process
Learn proper soldering iron safety and maintenance
Practice tinning the soldering iron
Create practice solder joints on perfboard
Learn to identify good vs bad solder joints
Practice desoldering techniques
Complete a simple soldering project
Understand breadboard layout and connections
Learn about power rails and distribution
Practice component placement and wire management
Build a simple LED circuit on breadboard
Learn to transfer circuits from schematic to breadboard
Document your first breadboard project
Build a basic circuit and identify what's wrong
Learn common circuit troubleshooting techniques
Practice using a multimeter to diagnose issues
Document common mistakes and their solutions
Create a troubleshooting checklist
Share your learning experience with others
Study the basic principles of Ohm's Law
Practice calculating voltage, current, and resistance
Build circuits to verify Ohm's Law calculations
Use a multimeter to measure and verify calculations
Complete Ohm's Law practice problems
Create a reference sheet for future use
Select a broken electronic device to repair
Research common issues for the device
Create a repair plan and gather tools
Document the repair process with photos
Test the repaired device thoroughly
Write up a repair guide for others
Learn basic multimeter safety
Practice setting up voltage measurement ranges
Measure DC voltage in various circuits
Learn to measure AC voltage safely
Create a voltage measurement log
Practice measuring voltage across components
Learn common schematic symbols
Practice drawing basic circuit schematics
Convert simple circuits to schematics
Learn to read component values from schematics
Practice with increasingly complex schematics
Create your own circuit schematic
Identify key sections of a datasheet (e.g., electrical characteristics, pin configurations).
Practice reading the datasheet for a simple component (e.g., 555 timer).
resources: Example datasheets from Digikey or Mouser.

tasks: Learn about Pulse Width Modulation (PWM).
Build a circuit to control LED brightness using a potentiometer.
Write code for a microcontroller (e.g., Arduino) to implement PWM for LED control.
resources: Potentiometer datasheet and example circuit diagrams.

tasks: Learn about desoldering tools (e.g., solder wick, desoldering pump).
Practice removing a resistor from a scrap PCB using solder wick.
resources: iFixit's 'How to Desolder Through-Hole Components' guide: https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+to+Desolder+Through-Hole+Components/75088

tasks: Learn how piezo buzzers work and how to drive them.
Create a circuit that plays a simple tone using a 555 timer.
Write code to generate different tones with a microcontroller.
resources: Piezo buzzer datasheet and circuit diagrams.

tasks: Learn to use schematic drawing software (e.g., Fritzing, KiCad).
Translate a simple LED circuit from a breadboard to a schematic.
resources: Breadboard setup examples and circuit drawing tutorials.

tasks: Understand the purpose of headers in electronics projects.
Practice soldering a row of male or female headers onto a practice PCB.
Verify connectivity using a multimeter.
resources: Practice PCBs with pre-drilled holes for headers.

tasks: Learn about operational amplifiers (op-amps) and their basic configurations (e.g., inverting, non-inverting).
Build a simple op-amp voltage follower or amplifier circuit.
Test the circuit using a multimeter or oscilloscope.
resources: Example op-amp circuit diagrams from Electronics Hub.
LM358 datasheet or similar op-amp datasheets.

tasks: Understand the basic controls of an oscilloscope (e.g., time base, voltage scale).
Measure a sine wave from a signal generator or an Arduino.
Practice triggering and capturing a stable waveform.
resources: Arduino or signal generator to create test waveforms.

tasks: Learn how infrared (IR) signals work.
Build a simple IR transmitter using an LED and a microcontroller.
Decode IR signals with an IR receiver module.
resources: Datasheets for IR LED and receiver components.
Practical IR remote projects for inspiration.

tasks: Learn about thermistors, LM35, or DS18B20 temperature sensors.
Build a circuit to read temperature data using a microcontroller.
Display the temperature data on an LCD or serial monitor.
resources: Datasheets for LM35 or DS18B20 sensors.

tasks: Learn to use PCB design software (e.g., KiCad, Eagle).
Design a simple circuit (e.g., LED with resistor) and lay it out in the software.
Export the Gerber files for manufacturing.
Learn how ultrasonic sensors work (e.g., HC-SR04).
Connect an ultrasonic sensor to a microcontroller and write code to measure distance.
Test the range finder with different objects and distances.
Understand the basics of programming microcontrollers in C.
Write a simple program to blink an LED using bare-metal code (no libraries).
Learn to configure timers and GPIO pins manually.
resources: Datasheets for microcontroller pin and timer configurations.
YouTube tutorials on bare-metal C programming.

tasks: Learn how DC motors and motor drivers work.
Assemble a robot car chassis with motors and a motor driver (e.g., L298N).
Write code to control the car’s movement using a microcontroller.
resources: L298N motor driver datasheet and wiring guides.

tasks: Learn about oscillators and how to generate audio frequencies.
Build a simple sound synthesizer using a 555 timer or op-amp.
Experiment with different resistor and capacitor values to change sound pitch.
resources: Examples of DIY synthesizers from Hackaday.
Datasheets for 555 timer and op-amp components.
